STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 3, 2023
Michelle Seigo
IONIA COUNTY DHHS
920 E LINCOLN AVE,
IONIA, MI, 48846-1393
RE: License#: CP340201198
Dear Michell Seigo:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on February 20-24, 2023 . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP340201198
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Michelle Seigo
Name of Agency: IONIA COUNTY DHHS
Agency Address: 920 E LINCOLN AVE
IONIA, MI 48846-1393
Agency Telephone #: 6165275200
Original Issuance Date: 05/01/1990
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Supervise
Independent Living, Place children in foster
home

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
R 400.12213 Record Management.
An agency shall do all of the following with respect to
maintenance of required records:
(b) Keep each record in a uniform fashion.
4 of 9 open case files (6 FC & 3 IL) included multiple documents uploaded in
preparation of the inspection, or during the inspection, despite these documents
being dated several months past.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement
(b) If the child is not returned to a parent, then the reason
why that’s not possible
(c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed with a
relative, then the reason why those placements are not
possible
(d) Consideration of the factors identified R 400.12404(4)
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child’s
age, appropriate to the child’s capacity to understand,
which includes an explanation to all relevant parties as to
why the change is necessary
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and the courts when applicable, of the
change in placement.
(h) The child’s new location and address

1 of 6 open foster care youth files reviewed contained a placement change action
summary, which documents all of the required information, was not completed
within the rule required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/15/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 3/31/2021
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
2 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that the
required information was provided to the caregiver timely, which would be
confirmed through the caregiver signature on the DHHHS-3307 and the timely
upload of the DHHS-3762 as well as a coordinating case contact documenting
these were provided.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
2 of 9 open youth case files (2 of 24 updated service plans) reviewed contained
reviewed updated service plans completed outside of the required timeframe.
These reports were completed 8 & 30 days late, respectively.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/15/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 3/31/2021
4/4/2022 Interim, CAP approved 4/20/2022
R400.12511 Termination.
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all
of the following information in the case record
within 30 calendar days of termination of its
services:
(a) The reason for the termination
(b) The youth’s new location

(c) A summary of the services provided during care
and the needs that remain to be met
(d) Provision for any follow-up services
1 of 2 closed cases of youth in Independent Living placements did not contain
documentation that all of the information required per the rule, which would be
documented on the action summary, was provided/completed timely. The action
summary was completed over 5 months past case closure.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as FOM 722-08E
3/15/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 3/31/2021
4/4/2022 Interim, CAP approved 4/20/2022
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP)
- within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business days
prior to a planned change of placement or no later than three
business days after an unplanned placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case closure
date or one business day after unplanned court ordered
dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is
used to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety concerns and
the safety plan, and any recommendations made for the family
during the FTM. The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business days of the FTM.
3 of 9 open case files (6 FC & 3 IL) did not contain documentation of all required
FTMs. 2 files were missing service plan development FTMs and 1 file was missing
the required FTM paperwork for 1 FTM documented to have been held.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/15/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 3/31/2021

FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are placed
apart
• Parents who are a member of a participating household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check yes
or no for the following when signing the treatment plan:
• I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan
and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review, and I will
have the opportunity to express my disagreement with
the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the
treatment plan, the caseworker must identify and document
actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s
participation in service planning and compliance with the
treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
3 of 9 open youth case files (9 of 29 treatment plans) reviewed were either missing
required signatures or contained signatures obtained over 30 days past the report
date.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/15/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 3/31/2021
4/4/2022 Interim, CAP approved 4/20/2022

FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the medical
passport verifying that s/he has sought and obtained the
necessary information under law and Michigan Department of
Health and Human Services (MDHHS) policy.
2 of 9 open case files (6 FC & 3 IL) did not contain documentation that medical
passports were generated and updated quarterly, as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/15/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 3/31/2021
4/4/2022 Interim, CAP approved 4/20/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Be sure electronic signatures are dated or there are social work contacts
documenting when the signatures were obtained.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was provided regarding cases that fall under DCWL purview for
the inspection.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows.
The agency has demonstrated overall compliance with the one CAP submitted. This
CAP was submitted in response to the 4/4/2022 licensing interim inspection report
and was approved on 4/20/22. The agency has reduced the number of citations
addressed in that CAP from 19 to 11 with 7 being repeat citations; however, the
number of incidents of violation within the repeats were also reduced. Of the 4

citations that were not repeats, from the 2022 inspection, 3 were cited in 1 specific
file and the other was related to file management due to documentation not being
uploaded to the files timely.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator assessment was reviewed and discussed during the
entrance meeting. The chief administrator accurately identified areas of non-
compliance which were largely attributed to staff performance resulting in
disciplinary action, staff burnout/turnover, and placement crisis.
Financial Overview
A financial audit was not required as this licensee is an MDHHS office.
Staff Interviews
The staff members interviewed reported no concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency appears to have sufficient workspace and equipment to perform the
required job functions. The CHRI and files are stored securely to prevent
unauthorized access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
_____________________________________03/01/2023
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 1, 2023
_____________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
